awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project will be across multiple industries that can benefit from regular monitoring of changes on the Earth's surface. Changes such as droughts, floods, deforestation, urbanization, and grain supply (acreage and yields) fluctuations have considerable impact on businesses as well as the environment. For example, it is estimated that US lost approximately 23 billion dollars due to drought in 2012. This I-Corps project will make use of vast amounts of satellite data to provide accurate, timely and actionable insights about these changes to customers in various industries such as commodity trading, crop insurance, and precision agriculture, pasture management. Our ability to track these changes at a global scale will also improve our understanding of the impact of climate and human induced changes on various ecosystems. 

This I-Corps project uses machine learning algorithms that analyze vast amounts of satellite imagery datasets to provide near real time as well as historical information about various changes on the Earth's surface. These algorithms were developed through various federal research grants which includes three NSF grants. Data products created using these algorithms have been validated to improve the state-of-the-art in several earth science applications such as forest fire mapping, surface water dynamics, palm oil plantation mapping, and crop mapping. The analytics technology is more generally applicable to other domains with similar underlying data characteristics. The commercial-use prototype will be developed with commodity traders providing expert feedback on their most meaningful use-cases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
Earth's surface has been going through tremendous changes due to human use and extreme weather events. These changes are leading to increased risk to human life, businesses, and wildlife. The team at the University of Minnesota has developed novel machine learning technologies to track these changes using petabytes of satellite imagery. Under this NSF I-Corps award, the team assessed the product-market fit from different aspects of business development and learned strategies to collect relevant insights through customer interviews and make informed decisions.

 During the I-corps program, the team conducted more than 100 interviews with potential customers and partners in four different market segments - agriculture commodity trading, hydropower forecasting, water resource management, and flood insurance. Through these interviews, we tested our understanding of customers' pain points and their willingness to pay. We also gained insights into different players involved in the decision-making process. I-corps instructors also taught us key concepts for analyzing the go-to-market strategies, effective ways to test value propositions and identify potential partners to bring the technology to market. The lessons learned during the program helped the team to prioritize market segments based on quantitative and qualitative feedback obtained from potential customers. 

The NSF I-corps program continues to help our team in bringing the technology to market. The market analysis helped the entrepreneurial lead of the project to identify a good product-market fit and submit a successful NSF-SBIR Phase I proposal. The experience gained during the I-Corps program is helping him to effectively test and iterate the MVP with customers, and build partnerships with key partners to launch the product. 

 


Last Modified: 06/13/2022
Modified by: Vipin Kumar
